page.content: tarmacadam, stone chippings, concrete, and receiving bettter pay. Or going down the mine, as Mr. Jeffries of New Works, now over 80, describes himself and all his brothers doing. He still lives close to the cottage where he was born. In his youth he worked as a gamekeeper, limestone quarrier, and coal miner. As well as which his family had a smallholding, which provided them with meat, poultry, vegetables, eggs, and milk. In the Second World War, many of the local women went to work in the iron works. Before the War it had employed around 700 men. Mr. Bert Underwood, who has lived in Little Wenock since 1923, a foreman in the works in the War, was a 'core maker' and recalls how they made tank landing craft.
